awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  P2C2--Controls on Water Isotope Variability in the Tropical Pacific: A Strategy to Improve Paleoclimate Interpretations
awd_abstract_narration:
Paleoclimate reconstructions of past tropical precipitation rely on interpreting hydrogen and oxygen isotopic variations in terms of past changes in precipitation.  This project has the goal of better understanding of the response of tropical Pacific precipitation to climatic variability and how the stable isotope composition of the rainfall is affected by seasonal and interannual changes in the climate.   The researchers include a scientist and a postdoctoral fellow from Georgia Institute of Technology and a scientist from the University of Colorado.  They will collect and measure the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in water vapor, rainfall and seawater from four island locations in the tropical Pacific.  Samples will be collected on site during field programs executed by the PIs.  The sampling program will also include year-round sampling by local individuals who will be trained in proper sampling techniques.  The sampling strategy includes ultra high-resolution sampling of the diurnal cycle, as well as daily and longer sampling in order to evaluate the relationship of water isotope variability to climate change from sub-seasonal to interannual time scales and on a basin wide scale.  The stable isotope data will be integrated with an isotope-enabled climate model at the National Center for Atmospheric Research to link the climate mechanisms for the isotope variability at high frequency with the resulting longer term averaged values that typify the type of data reconstructed by paleoclimate proxies of rainfall.  Using this approach, the PIs hope to provide a more accurate evaluation of paleoclimate proxies as well as a better understanding of the uncertainties embedded in these types of reconstructions.

The recent rise in the number of paleoclimate publications dedicated to measuring and interpreting water stable isotopes, and the possibly oversimplified nature of some of the interpretations, makes this project likely to have a significant impact on paleoclimate research.  The project includes two established researchers, Kim Cobb (GA. Tech.) and David Noone (CU), but the main driver of this project is Jessica Conroy, an EAR Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Ga. Tech., supported by the AGS Paleoclimate Program.  This project builds on the PRF award by providing greater access to the Pacific for sampling, collaboration with Noone at CU for access to the NCAR GCMs, and a third year of support for the postdoc to complete the work.

Prepared by PI Kim Cobb (Georgia Tech) on behalf of Co-PI’s Jessica Conroy (U. Illinois) & David Noone (CU-Boulder, now at OSU)

Summary of Activities, Accomplishments, and Findings

            The projected impacts of anthropogenic climate change on the global water cycle are profound, yet many aspects of the global water budget, and its evolution through time, remain poorly characterized in the observational record as well as in climate models. Records of past precipitation spanning the last centuries to millennia can supplement the short instrumental record of precipitation and aid in identifying anthropogenic trends in vulnerable regions. However, most so-called paleo-hydrology records rely on variations in water isotopes as proxies that are thought to reflect large-scale circulation, evaporation, and precipitation, even though observations of water isotopes are extremely scant in the modern day. The funded research developed a new, large-scale network of water isotope observation stations across the tropical Pacific, where water isotope observations are particularly scarce in space and time. By analyzing the resulting water isotope data from seawater, rainwater, and water vapor samples, the PIs identified the dominant physical processes shaping water isotope variations in the atmosphere as well as the sea surface across a wide variety of tropical settings (i.e. the drylands of Galapagos to a remote low-lying atoll in the middle of the Pacific to the jungles of Papau New Guinea). In all, the PIs established six new sites for long-term water isotope monitoring, where daily rainfall samples and weekly seawater samples are collected by unpaid collaborators. The network was fully-established when the record-breaking El Niño event of 2015/2016 occurred, and continued through the moderate La Niña event of 2016/2017. The lead PI organized for the collection and analysis of hundreds of additional water isotope samples from two ships of opportunity – the NOAA-funded Rapid Response El Niño cruise in Jan 2016, and an NSF-funded research cruise in Jan 2017, vastly augmenting the spatial extent of the water isotope dataset. The resulting water isotope data comprise a one-of-a-kind community resource for i) probing the response of the tropical water cycle to a large natural climate extreme, with implications for the reconstruction of El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) extremes in paleoclimate records, ii) assessing the accuracy of global climate model simulations of ENSO extremes. Most importantly, the water isotope observing network remains fully operational, and hopefully it will motivate the creation of an international water isotope observational network as part of the TPOS2020 initiative and/or the relevant Global Ocean Observing Systems platforms. Overall, the funded research demonstrates the power of using water isotope observations in vapor, rainfall, and seawater as diagnostic tools for hydrological processes, and their representation in ocean and atmospheric models, as well as a means to unlock the full potential of water isotope-based paleoclimate records. The funded research resulted in the publication of six scholarly articles in peer-reviewed journals, one undergraduate Honor’s Thesis, one graduate Dissertation.

            The funded research advanced the careers of nine female scientists, including two high school students, two Georgia Tech undergraduate research assistants, two Georgia Tech graduate students, three Georgia Tech postdoctoral scholars (including coPI Conroy, now an Assistant Professor), and lead PI Cobb. Public engagement activities related to the funded research include presentations at elementary schools in Republic of Kiribati schools, at staff meetings at Gunung Mulu National Park, in Malaysian Borneo, as well as numerous public lectures and media appearances about climate change by lead PI Cobb.
